intro: Scilla sardensis, commonly known as the Sardinian squill, is a flowering plant native to the island of Sardinia. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its striking blue or purple bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. Scilla sardensis has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces umbels of flowers in spring. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has cultural significance in Mediterranean regions.
